dublinCore.dc:title: 113 HR 4756 IH: Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Cartwright (for himself and Mr. Michaud) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce

form.official-title: To require reporting of bullying to appropriate authorities and assist with equal protection claims against entities who fail to respond appropriately to bullying, and for other purposes.

section.text:
This Act may be cited as the
Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act
or the
BRAVE Act
.
Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 ( 20 U.S.C. 7801 et seq. ) is amended by inserting after section 9534 the following:

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (B), a local educational agency shall require an employee of the local educational agency who becomes aware of bullying to report to the individual designated under paragraph (2) by not later than 7 business days after becoming aware of such bullying a description of—

clause.text: if the bullying included a reference to or was motivated by an actual or perceived protected characteristic of the victim, such protected characteristic; and
the response to such bullying by employees of the local educational agency.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding subparagraph (A), in the case of an employee of a local educational agency who is informed of bullying by a student attending a school served by the local educational agency, but the student requests that such bullying not be reported by the employee, the employee shall not be required to report such bullying under subparagraph (A).

paragraph.text: A local educational agency shall designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and shall inform each employee of the local educational agency of the contact information of the individual so designated.

paragraph.header: Reporting to the local educational agency
paragraph.text: Not later than 60 days after the date of the receipt of a report under paragraph (1), the individual designated under paragraph (2) shall inform all employees of the local educational agency of the acts described and the response by employees of the local educational agency and shall exclude any personally identifiable information of any student involved.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (B), a local educational agency shall publish and make available to all students served by the local educational agency and parents of such students a report on a quarterly basis that—

clause.text: summarizes the bullying reported since the previous quarterly report;
summarizes the responses by employees of the local educational agency to such bullying;
excludes any personally identifiable information of any student involved; and
informs the public of the right to file a complaint under subsection (b)(2).

subparagraph.text: A local educational agency shall not publish a report under subparagraph (A) in a case in which such publication would reveal personally identifiable information about an individual student.

paragraph.text: Each local educational agency shall review, on an annual basis, the policies on bullying for schools served by the local educational agency.
As a condition of receiving funds under this Act, a local educational agency shall—

subparagraph.text: annually certify to the Secretary in writing that such local educational agency has complied with this section; and
together with such certification, submit the 4 most recent quarterly reports published preceding such certification pursuant to subsection (a)(4).

paragraph.text: The Assistant Secretary who serves as the head of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education shall—

subparagraph.text: establish a procedure for a student of a local educational agency, a parent of such student, or another appropriate individual to submit to the Assistant Secretary a complaint relating to a failure to comply with this section; and
publish such procedure on the Internet website of the Department of Education.

paragraph.text: After receiving a complaint pursuant to paragraph (2), the Assistant Secretary shall—

subparagraph.text: investigate such complaint to determine if a local educational agency failed to comply with this section; and
if such local educational agency is determined under subparagraph (A) to have failed to comply with this section—

clause.text: withhold further payment of funds under this Act to such local educational agency;
issue a complaint to compel compliance of such local educational agency through a cease and desist order; or
enter into a compliance agreement with such local educational agency to bring it into compliance with this section,

subparagraph.continuation-text: in the same manner as the Secretary is authorized to take such actions under sections 455, 456, and 457, respectively, of the General Education Provisions Act.

paragraph.header: Public availability of information about complaints
paragraph.text: Not later than 60 days after receiving a complaint pursuant to subsection (b)(2), the Assistant Secretary shall make available on the Internet website of the Department of Education information about such complaint, which shall—

subparagraph.text: if the bullying included a reference to or was motivated by an actual or perceived protected characteristic of the victim, include a description of such protected characteristic; and
exclude any personally identifiable information of any student involved.

paragraph.text: The term bullying means any severe, pervasive, or persistent electronic, written, verbal, or physical act by one student or a group of students toward another student during school hours and on school premises, or at a school-sponsored activity outside of school hours, that causes—

subparagraph.text: harm to or reasonable concern for the person, property, or mental health of such other student; or
such other student to withdraw from or avoid benefitting from the services, activities, or opportunities offered by the school.

paragraph.text: The term protected characteristic includes race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
